section.title: Logarithmic Functions Activity
section.p: Logarithms can sometimes be the source of much turmoil and angst to students. To some members of the English department, the word logarithms is used as a joke to respond to something that is confusing, Is that like logarithms? (laughter ensues).
But you will not have these issues, because logarithms are not bad, they're just spelled that way. Remember this, in short, a logarithm is essentially an exponent.

This activity is an introduction to logarithms and the logarithmic function. And since logarithms are exponents, it is a good idea to review some key properties of exponents, in particular negative and fractional exponents.

subsection.p: The math word log is short for logarithm. It means log base 10. But we can use any positive number as a base, so \log_b means log base b.
Since \log is base 10 (powers of 10) we technically should write \log_{10}, but base 10 is so often used, we leave out the 10 for convenience.
Another often used logarithm is base e. It's called the natural logarithm and is written \ln. Again, technically we should write \log_e, but we write \ln for convenience.
All other logarithms are written in standard format. The base, b, indicates what number is being multiplied over and over. So if 2 is the base, we write \log_2 which indicates powers of 2.

subsection.title: The Range of a Logarithmic Function
subsection.p: Earlier we used graphs to answer the questions: What power of 10 gives you 36? and What power of 10 gives you 0.6?
We answered the questions using logarithm statements: \log(36) \approx 1.556 and \log(0.6) \approx -0.222
Notice with just a base 10 we can use positive or negative exponents to get any positive result we want.
You want to get a result of 36? Use a power of about 1.556 as in 10^{1.556} \approx 36
You want to get a result of 0.6? Use a power of about -0.222 as in 10^{-0.222} \approx 0.6.
Remember logarithms are exponents and clearly we can use both positive and negative exponents.
Logarithms tell you the power you need to get a particular result. You input the result you want, the function tells you the exponent you need. The exponent is the output.

statement.p: What power of 10 gives you 1?

subsection.p: Given an input from the domain of a logarithmic function, the range can be positive, negative or zero. In fact, the range is all real numbers.

assemblage.p: If \log_{b}(x)=y then y is any real number.

subsection.title: Rules of Logarithms
subsection.p: In order for this part of the activity to make sense, we must remember what a base and an exponent are. Remember in the expression b^x, b is the base and x is the exponent. The exponent literally counts how many times you multiplied the base. For instance b^7 means \overbrace{b\cdot b\cdot b\cdot b\cdot b\cdot b\cdot b}^{7\text{ times}}.

subsubsection.p: Now let's take some obvious information that you already concluded above to discover a not-so-obvious property of logarithms.

Start with the simple equation 8\cdot16=128\text{.}Apply the \log_2(\phantom{x}) function to both sides of the equation to get \log_2(8\cdot16)=\log_2(128)\text{.} Notice on the right side we already know the answer (i.e. the power of 2 that gives you 128)

statement.p: What power of 2 gives you 128?

subsubsection.p: Now you can write the equation \log_{2}(8\cdot16)=\log_{2}(128) as \log_{2}(8\cdot16)=7\text{.}

Notice on the left side of the equation:
There are 3 factors of 2 in 8. That's why \log_{2}(8)=3.
There are 4 factors of 2 in 16. That's why \log_{2}(8)=4. So the simple equation 7=3+4, can be written using logarithms
7=3+4 7=\log_{2}(8)+\log_{2}(16) \log_{2}(128)=\log_{2}(8)+\log_{2}(16) \log_{2}(8 \cdot 16)=\log_{2}(8)+\log_{2}(16)
Yes, you just discovered that \log_2(8\cdot16)=\log_2(8)+\log_2(16)\text{.} In fact this property applies to all log_{b}(x)

subsubsection.title: Rule: Bring Down the Exponent
subsubsection.p: We start with something obvious. You already know that instead of writing 8+8+8+8 you could just write 4\cdot8.
Maybe you never thought about it, but multiplication is just repeated addition. It's a shortcut way to write the same thing over and over.
On the other hand, exponents are just repeated multiplication. Exponents are a shortcut way to write the same thing multiplied over and over.

Consider the expression \log(8\cdot8\cdot8\cdot8). We can use some shortcuts to write the expression in at least two different ways.\log(8\cdot8\cdot8\cdot8)=\log\mathopen{}\left(8^4\right)\mathclose{} and using the last rule we discovered about the log of a product \log(8\cdot8\cdot8\cdot8)=\log(8)+\log(8)+\log(8)+\log(8)\text{.}
Since both shortcuts must give the same answer, we get\log\mathopen{}\left(8^4\right)\mathclose{}=\log(8)+\log(8)+\log(8)+\log(8)

subsubsection.title: Rule: Log of a Quotient
subsubsection.p: This rule you will discover using the two rules you already know.
Remember that a negative exponent means reciprocal so a quotient can be rewritten as a product \frac{Q}{P}=Q \cdot P^{-1}

statement.p: Consider the expression \log_{b}\mathopen{}\left(\frac{A}{B}\right)\mathclose{}
Use a negative exponent to rewrite the fraction inside the log function as a product.
The right side of the equation is now a product of two values.
Use the rule \log_b(A\cdot B)=\log_b(A)+\log_b(B) to rewrite the right side as the sum of two log terms.

The last term on the right side has a value with a negative exponent. Use the rule log_{b}(N^{x})=x \log_{b}(N) to bring down the negative exponent so the second term is now adding a negative. Rewrite the right side after the negative exponent is brought down.
The entire right side can now be written as a difference (subtraction).
